message_1: Question: If one twin travels at a velocity of 0.8c for 5 years while the other twin stays on Earth, how much younger will the twin on Earth be compared to the traveling twin when they are reunited? (Assume they were both born at the same time and neglect any other complicating factors.)
message_2:
This is a classic example of the Twin Paradox in special relativity. To solve this problem, we need to use the time dilation formula:

Δt' = Δt / √(1 - v^2/c^2)

where Δt' is the time experienced by the traveling twin, Δt is the time experienced by the twin on Earth, v is the velocity of the traveling twin (0.8c), and c is the speed of light.

First, let's find the time experienced by the traveling twin:

Δt' = 5 years / √(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)
Δt' = 5 years / √(1 - 0.64)
Δt' = 5 years / √(0.36)
Δt' = 5 years / 0.6
Δt' ≈ 8.33 years

So, the traveling twin experiences approximately 8.33 years of time during their journey. Since the twin on Earth experiences 5 years of time, the difference in their ages when they are reunited is:

Age difference = 8.33 years - 5 years = 3.33 years

The twin on Earth will be approximately 3.33 years younger than the traveling twin when they are reunited.
